by ALAN HIRSCH
The CUS approved yesterday a
measure that will allow students
to take Independent studies and
Research projects pass-fail, and
discussed a proposal to move the
add-drop date back four weeks.
Under the Independent study
grading provisions, students will
be able to take independent work
either for a grade or on a pass-fail
basis. At present, independent
work can only be taken for a
grade.
The CUS approved the
measure by a vote of 6-2.
Dissenting votes were cast by two
of the four student

representatives, Dan Holik and
Nancy Brighton.
The proposal to shift the
add-drop date to four weeks into
the Semester was submitted by
Undergraduate Coordinator
Frederick Dierman as part of a
plan to make the deadline for all
changes in registration the same
date.
Complaints
According to Holik, Diernian's
proposal was prompted by
complaints that the Registrar's
Office has substantial, difficulty
with the different dates for
changes in Independent study,
pass-fail, and add -drop

registration. Under the current
system, the add-drop date is eight
weeks into the semester, while
that for Independent study and
pass-fail is already four weeks.
"I feel this proposal has little
chance to pass the CUS--at least I
hope there's not," said Holik.
Holik stated, though, that
"there is some support on the
CUS for the measure."
The committee is scheduled to
vote on the shift of the add-drop
date at its next meeting April 24.
The shift in the Independent
study/Research policy will. in
effect, reduce the "grade glut"
for those projects, said Holik. A

DeBakey to talk in Shriver
Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, world
renowned cardiovascular surgeon
and medical stateman, will
deliver a lecture entitled "The
Political Aspects of Medicine" on
Tuesday at 7 pm in Shriver Hall.
K wown chiefly for his
pioneering efforts in vascular
surgery, DeBakey has made
contributions to medical
instrumentation and technique.
His most widely acclaimed
efforts have entailed work with
aneurisms, surgery to alleviate
strokes, and organ transplant
procedures.
A distinguished medical
educator, he is also President and
Chairman of the Department of
Surgery of the Baylor College of
Medicine and Director of the
Cardiovascular Research Training
Center of the Methodist Hospital
in Houston.

skills have had a great deal of
influence on public policies and
international standards of health
and medical care delivery. Past

Chairman of the President's
Commission on Hearth Disease,
Cancer and Stroke, DeBakey
continues to devote considerable
time to advisory health
committees.

consultative appointments is
membership in the National
Advisory Heart and Lung Council
of the National Institutes of
Health. He also serves on a
committee advising Congressional
leaders on National Health plans.

and fellowship in numerous

and is a past President of the
International Cardiovascular
Society, the American
Association for Thoracic Surgery,
and the Society for Vascular
Surgery, among others. He is an
honorary member or fellow or
several foreign medical societies.

honorary member of the
Academy of Medical Sciences of
the U.S.S.R.

Bookstore cites faculty negligence in ordering books
By BOB BUCHANAN
Hopkins faculty have
consistently failed to submit
booklists to Follett's Bookcenter
on time, resulting in difficulties
for students in obtaining required
texts, according to Bookcenter
Manager, Jack Sanders.
A letter from Textbook
Manager Esta Baker to former
Dean of Students Robert
Fitzpatrick shows that 59 per
cent of listings from professors
were received past the May 21
deadline for the Fall semester,
1974.
The letter stipulates that "the
Evening College was only
marginally better with a 50.7 per
cent delinquency rate after their
May 10 deadline.'
In an October letter to
Fitzpatrick, Sanders termed the
problem "our biggest headache."
Sanders adds that at present

the problem is particularly acut,
since publishers are now
demanding that orders be placed
on time in ordertO control
inventories more closely. He
stated that due to economic
exigencies publishers "want their
money now" and are not printing
books untill guaranteed demand
in the form of new orders.
Also, Follet's policy of
repurchasing used books has been
severely hampered by the
faculty's lack of cooperation
according to Sanders. The
bookstore will pay students 50
per cent of the suggested retail
price for old hard bound books
which will be used the following
semester, regardless of condition,
Without Course book lists the
implementation of the policy has
been hampered.
However, Sanders stated to the
ad hoc Homewood Advisory

committee investigating book
store pricing policies that "used
books do not seem to be a real
factor on this campus." He
co n t inued,"Generally speaking,
the used books don't sell the first
day...[students] want to buy
new books."
Sanders' observation is
corroborated by a survey
conducted by the ad hoc
committee. An overwhelming
number of students stated that
they would "definitely" not sell
back their books for courses in
their major.
In an attempt to solve the
problem of faculty submitting
course book lists late, Sanders
wrote a series of letters to
Fitzpatrick explaining the
problem. According to Sanders,
new Dean of Students Jakie Hall
has been advised of the situation.

'Next Step' features Bella Abzug
By JAN HAMMERMAN
"Next Step: A Festival of
Women" will continue with a
lecture by outspoken New York'
Congresswoman Bella Abzug on
Monday, April 14. The speech
will be held in Shriver Hall at
8:00 pm.
Abzug, a three-term member
of the House of Representatives,.
has been an advocate of women's
rights, cutbacks in military
spending, and an end to
government secrecy on U.S.
activities in Southeast Asia.
Accoring to Virginia Donovan,
lecture coordinator for the
Women's Center, "Abzug was
invited so that Next Step would
have a good balance of speakers:
Greer on literature, Margaret
Mead in social science, and Bella
in politics." Donovan added that
the Center has attempted to
bring Abzug to Hopkins for the
past three years.
Originally, the political
speaker was to be Barbara
Jordan, a Texas Congresswoman.
Donovan explained though, that
she was unavailable at the time.
Long a proponent of a more
active role for women in national
politics. Abzug helped to
establish the National Women's
Caucus and has spoken on this
topic at several college
campuses.
Moreover, she has been a
major sponsor of legislation in
the fields of pollution, civil
liberties, and aid to the urban
poor.
Ahzug was also an early and

vocal critic of - United States
policy in Vietnam, leading the
fight for the Vietnam
Disengagement Act. The
congresswoman recently returned
from a fact-finding mission in
Indochina and is opposed to
continued military aid for the
Lon Nol and Thieu governments.
Abzug is one of the most
controversial members of
Congress, whose support of a bill
can, at times, cost the sponsor
"twenty or thirty votes"
according to The Almanac of
Anerican Politics.
A native New Yorker, Bella
Abzug graduated from Hunter
College, where she was President
of the Student Council, and from

Columbia University Law School,
where she edited The Columbia
Law kview.
Abzug has been a practicing
attorney since 1947, specializing
in labor law and civil rights cases.
Among her most notable
achievements are her challenges
of the traditional practice of
excluding Blacks from jury duty
and the unequal application of
capital punishment.
On April 14, the "Next Step"
series will also present "The
Future of Political Philosophy" a
discussion lead by Enid Block,
assistant professor of political
science. This program will
kick-off the faculty lecture
segment of the symposium.

In an \effort to simplify and reduce the paperwork for the
Registrar, Undergraduate Coordinator Dr. Frederick Dierman
has offered an add-drop proposal that was considered totally
unacceptable by undergraduates at the beginning of this year.
Last we heard, the CUS had all kinds of options for the
add-drop date--changing it to four weeks into the semester
with recorded "withdrawals" 'after that, extending it to 13
weeks, or some variation on that theme.
While members of the administration called the . issue' of
add-drop not that important" and basically a matter of
"bookkeeping," when it was brought before the CUS a year
ago, students obviously felt it was important enough to keep
the add-drop date after mid-semester that close to a thousand
students petitioned for its extension. Moreover, the extension
for certain classes, such as freshman Chem last year, so that
students can see their midterms before deciding whtther or
not to drop a course, indicates that the administration has
found a later drop date to be beneficial to students, at least
in some respects.
Dierman's argument for moving back the add-drop date is
a woefully unconvincing one, motivated by a concern for
clerical convenience rather than what students have felt and
continue to .feel is in their best interest. Let the add-drop
date be one good thing that doesn't have to come to an end
just yet, huh?

Tuitions crunch middle incomes
By MARC DUVO1SIN
As the cost of higher
education continues to rise.
American colleges and
universities face a dilemma
concerning the assessment and
the allocation of financial aid.
Financial aid programs have
traditionally tended to favor the
lower income group. However, as
tuition and other fees steadily
increase, the middle income
student must be included in
financial aid eligibility, though
existing assistance programs
cannot provide adequate aid' .to
the middle income sector.
"The middle income is the one
bracket that is squeezed out."
observed Larry Denton, Director
of Academic Services. This
problem is a serious one, since
middle income students comprise
a sizeable portion of private
university enrollments. At
Ilopkins, roughly 70 per cent of
the undergraduate student body
falls into this category, by
Denton's estimate.
"In the sixties," explained
Denton, "the price of a college
education was ..it too much for
those in the middle income
bracket." The increasing costs" of
private education, though, have
imposed a strain on the middle
income family which must be
acknowledged in the needs
analysis process.
Though standards for financial
aid eligibility have been
expanded in an effort to include
the middle income group, funds

from the federal government and
other sources have not been
increased enough to provide
adequate-aid to this group:
What is needed to make the
allocation of aid more complete
is "a massive infusion of money,"
observed Erik Molander,
chairman of the Student
Council's Financial Aid
Committee.
"Needs analysis has been
redone and made more sensitive
to the middle income needs," he
stated, "but there still isn't
enough funding to allocate aid to
meet this need."
Since the middle income
student is Hopkins' "bread and
butter student" in Denton's
words, Hopkins administrators
have begun to investigate
methods of increasing aid to the
middle income sector.
Denton contends that a merit
scholarship program, presently
under' consideration by ' the
Committee on Admissions and
Academic Services, would help.
"We have programs for lower
income students, but nothing of
real value to the middle income
group. I think that a merit
scholarships program could fill
this need."
Molander contends, though,
that merit scholarships would not
be a viable solution to the
problem. "Today, that just isn't a
rational solution. People won't
be receptive to the 'idea of just
handing out money."
Denton and Molander agree

that the largest problem is a
simple lack of funds to be
allocated in accordance with the
needs analysis. The new, more
liberal needs analysis, though
more equitable and more
sensitive to the middle income
group, has increased the total
amount of need far beyond that
which can be met in the current
financial aid structure.
"The new analysis is better,"
stated Molander, "but it just
increased the amount of need."
He said that, as a result, the
allocation of need becomes
"relative deprivation," since
student in both the lower and
middle income groups cannot
receive allocations equal to their
analyzed need. "There just isn't
enough money," observed
Molander.
Unless the financial aid
structure is made more sensitive,
especially with regard to federal
funding, Molander predicts that
private education "may cease to
be a viable idea—people are
already having to go to sta.te
schools."
Molander said he feels Hopkins
should increase its loan program,
petition for better federal
funding, and consider emergency
measures which have been taken
at other schools.
Yale University has enacted a
tuition payment option, whereby
students may elect either to pay
tuition with financial aid or pay
no tuition and agree to forward
.025 per cent of their income to

Larry
Yale for the rest of their lives.
Also, at Beloit College a
sliding tuition program has been
instituted which requires
students to pay as much tuition
as they can afford according to
their needs analysis. Molander
asserted that Beloit is dissatisfied
with the program though, and
may discontinue it.
Hopkins may be forced to
consider taking its own measures
to help out the middle income
bracket. Statistics compiled by
the Admissions Council show
that 21 per cent of those
students who turned down
Hopkins' offer of acceptance did
so for financial reason . "Most
of them end up going to state
schools," stated Molander.
C. Wayne Hood, Hopkins'
Director of Financial Aid, is a
member of a committee of
college financial aid
administrators which is
examining the needs analysis
rocess with an e e towards

Denton
updating its criteria.
Denton stated that Hopkins'
Academic Services administration
is sensitive to the plight of the
middle income student. "We
realize the situation middle
income students are in," he said.
"I consider it a very serious
problem."
Hopkins currently provides ail
to needy undergraduates through
federal grants and loans and a
.limited supply of University
grants and loans. However, this
current structure is not
sufficiently sensitive to the needs
of the middle income student.
Barring an increase in federal
funding or a reversal of the
nations's economy, Denton,
foresees Ole frightening
possibility of private colleges
"accepting students on the basis
of whether they can meet the
costs."
"It's a serious situation," he
stated, "given the state of the
economy."

committee. An overwhelming

problem of faculty submitting
course book lists late, Sanders
wrote a series of letters to
Fitzpatrick explaining the
problem. According to Sanders,
new Dean of Students Jakie Hall

Tuitions crunch middle incomes
By MARC DUVO1SIN
As the cost of higher
education continues to rise.
American colleges and
universities face a dilemma
concerning the assessment and
the allocation of financial aid.
Financial aid programs have
traditionally tended to favor the
lower income group. However, as
tuition and other fees steadily
increase, the middle income
student must be included in
financial aid eligibility, though
existing assistance programs
cannot provide adequate aid' .to
the middle income sector.
"The middle income is the one
bracket that is squeezed out."
observed Larry Denton, Director
of Academic Services. This
problem is a serious one, since
middle income students comprise
a sizeable portion of private
university enrollments. At
Ilopkins, roughly 70 per cent of
the undergraduate student body
falls into this category, by
Denton's estimate.
"In the sixties," explained
Denton, "the price of a college
education was ..it too much for
those in the middle income
bracket." The increasing costs" of
private education, though, have
imposed a strain on the middle
income family which must be
acknowledged in the needs
analysis process.
Though standards for financial
aid eligibility have been
expanded in an effort to include
the middle income group, funds

from the federal government and
other sources have not been
increased enough to provide
adequate-aid to this group:
What is needed to make the
allocation of aid more complete
is "a massive infusion of money,"
observed Erik Molander,
chairman of the Student
Council's Financial Aid
Committee.
"Needs analysis has been
redone and made more sensitive
to the middle income needs," he
stated, "but there still isn't
enough funding to allocate aid to
meet this need."
Since the middle income
student is Hopkins' "bread and
butter student" in Denton's
words, Hopkins administrators
have begun to investigate
methods of increasing aid to the
middle income sector.
Denton contends that a merit
scholarship program, presently
under' consideration by ' the
Committee on Admissions and
Academic Services, would help.
"We have programs for lower
income students, but nothing of
real value to the middle income
group. I think that a merit
scholarships program could fill
this need."
Molander contends, though,
that merit scholarships would not
be a viable solution to the
problem. "Today, that just isn't a
rational solution. People won't
be receptive to the 'idea of just
handing out money."
Denton and Molander agree

that the largest problem is a
simple lack of funds to be
allocated in accordance with the
needs analysis. The new, more
liberal needs analysis, though
more equitable and more
sensitive to the middle income
group, has increased the total
amount of need far beyond that
which can be met in the current
financial aid structure.
"The new analysis is better,"
stated Molander, "but it just
increased the amount of need."
He said that, as a result, the
allocation of need becomes
"relative deprivation," since
student in both the lower and
middle income groups cannot
receive allocations equal to their
analyzed need. "There just isn't
enough money," observed
Molander.
Unless the financial aid
structure is made more sensitive,
especially with regard to federal
funding, Molander predicts that
private education "may cease to
be a viable idea—people are
already having to go to sta.te
schools."
Molander said he feels Hopkins
should increase its loan program,
petition for better federal
funding, and consider emergency
measures which have been taken
at other schools.
Yale University has enacted a
tuition payment option, whereby
students may elect either to pay
tuition with financial aid or pay
no tuition and agree to forward
.025 per cent of their income to

Larry
Yale for the rest of their lives.
Also, at Beloit College a
sliding tuition program has been
instituted which requires
students to pay as much tuition
as they can afford according to
their needs analysis. Molander
asserted that Beloit is dissatisfied
with the program though, and
may discontinue it.
Hopkins may be forced to
consider taking its own measures
to help out the middle income
bracket. Statistics compiled by
the Admissions Council show
that 21 per cent of those
students who turned down
Hopkins' offer of acceptance did
so for financial reason . "Most
of them end up going to state
schools," stated Molander.
C. Wayne Hood, Hopkins'
Director of Financial Aid, is a
member of a committee of
college financial aid
administrators which is
examining the needs analysis
rocess with an e e towards

Denton
updating its criteria.
Denton stated that Hopkins'
Academic Services administration
is sensitive to the plight of the
middle income student. "We
realize the situation middle
income students are in," he said.
"I consider it a very serious
problem."
Hopkins currently provides ail
to needy undergraduates through
federal grants and loans and a
.limited supply of University
grants and loans. However, this
current structure is not
sufficiently sensitive to the needs
of the middle income student.
Barring an increase in federal
funding or a reversal of the
nations's economy, Denton,
foresees Ole frightening
possibility of private colleges
"accepting students on the basis
of whether they can meet the
costs."
"It's a serious situation," he
stated, "given the state of the
economy."
